discussion.content: A for me too

questions.question_text:
An organization has the following password policies:
✑ Passwords must be at least 16 characters long.
✑ A password cannot be the same as any previous 20 passwords.
✑ Three failed login attempts will lock the account for five minutes.
Passwords must have one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one non-alphanumeric symbol.
//IMG//

A database server was recently breached, and the incident response team suspects the passwords were compromised. Users with permission on that database server were forced to change their passwords for that server. Unauthorized and suspicious logins are now being detected on a completely separate server.
Which of the following is MOST likely the issue and the best solution?

choices.B: The organization has improperly configured single sign-on; the organization should implement a RADIUS server to control account logins.
choices.A: Some users are reusing passwords for different systems; the organization should scan for password reuse across systems.
choices.D: The trust relationship between the two servers has been compromised; the organization should place each server on a separate VLAN.
choices.C: User passwords are not sufficiently long or complex; the organization should increase the complexity and length requirements for passwords.

questions.question_text: Ann, a user, reports she is receiving emails that appear to be from organizations to which she belongs, but the emails contain links to websites that do not belong to those organizations. Which of the following security scenarios does this describe?

choices.A: A hacker is using Ann's social media information to create a spear phishing attack
choices.B: The DNS servers for the organizations have been hacked and are pointing to malicious sites
choices.D: Ann's computer is infected with adware that has changed the email links
choices.C: The company's mail system has changed the organization's links to point to a proxy server for security

discussion.content:
A is correct. An example of Spear Phishing:
As an example, an attacker might try to impersonate the CEO of an
organization in an email. It’s relatively simple to change the header of an
email so that the From field includes anything, including the CEO’s name
and title. Attackers can send an email to all employees requesting that they
reply with their password. Because the email looks like it’s coming from the
CEO, these types of phishing emails fool uneducated users.

How about D?
"Adware might even replace the legitimate ads and web content with ads that benefit the malware author." Mike Chapple

comments.content: Adware will not change the links in emails. The emails appear to be a phishing attempt and because it says they are seemingly from the organizations she is apart of then it only makes sense that it is targeted, meaning spear phishing.

discussion.content:
A is the only one that makes sense. The hacker uses her social media to find out what organizations she's part of then performs a spear phishing attack and tries to (and apparently successfully) gets her to click the link.

B would make sense in explaining why the links lead elsewhere, but does not explain why she is getting multiple emails targeted at her
C,D don't make sense
"appear to be" , so they actually are probably NOT from those organisations => phishing
A +1, agree

comments.content: I'm a bit late to your question, but here's some practical reasoning for 'A': since Ann is the only user reporting this issue, as well as the fact that the emails are from organizations that she specifically belongs to, it cannot be a problem belonging to a piece of hardware (only her workstation, the remote server, etc) and would most likely originate from Ann's social media page that states what organizations she belongs to.

discussion.content: why is this answer A? the questions does not mention anything about social media?

choices.D: SSL is not the correct protocol to use in this situation; change to TLS and try the client-server connection again
choices.B: The remote server cannot support SHA-256; try another hashing algorithm like SHA-1 and see if the application can connect
choices.A: The date is past the certificate expiration; reset the system to the current time and see if the connection still fails
choices.C: AES is date/time dependent; either reset the system time to the correct time or try a different encryption approach

discussion.content: I guess... A? Not any other.
I go with A bc the question is not even balance in my head

questions.question_text: An application developer is working on a new calendar and scheduling application. The developer wants to test new functionality that is time/date dependent and set the local system time to one year in the future. The application also has a feature that uses SHA-256 hashing and AES encryption for data exchange. The application attempts to connect to a separate remote server using SSL, but the connection fails. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause and next step?

discussion.content: 2 discs can be down in RAID 6, any other only 1 at the time
Why is it not raid 1. A raid 1 would have 5 drives mirrored. it would allow 4 failures.http://www.raid-calculator.com/default.aspx

RAID 6 can protect against two disk failures
Because RAID 6 uses a double parity scheme, it can protect against the simultaneous failure of two disks. RAID 10 may or may not be able to protect against two disk failures depending on where they occur

RAID 6
RAID 6 can sustain 2 drive failures instead of 1. This is achieved again with the help of parity. In raid level 6, double distributed parity is used to achieve this level of redundancy.

Raid 10 is a good solution that will give you both the performance advantage of raid 0 and also the redundancy of raid 1 mirroring.
Clearly, RAID 6 provides better redundancy than RAID 10 because it provides the redundancy of RAID 1.
RAID 6 correct. while RAID 10 is a desirable answer RAID 10 are usually arrange in even numbers. Since the question states 5 drives. Therefore RAID 10 is not a viable answer anymore.

comments.content: Raid 1 should be the answer as it can support up to 4 drive failures

discussion.content: Because RAID 6 uses a double parity scheme, it can protect against the simultaneous failure of two disks. RAID 10 may or may not be able to protect against two disk failures depending on where they occur.https://searchdatabackup.techtarget.com/tip/RAID-6-vs-RAID-10

comments.content: It doesn't actually; RAID 10 can only use even number of drives, so it cant support 5.

discussion.content: RAID 6 has more redundancy than RAID10, question ask for Most Fault-tolerant , my guess RAID6

comments.content: Raid 10 is the better but you need an even number of drives. The question states that they have 5 to use.

discussion.content:
Raid 10. D is the answer.

This is best suitable for heavy IO usage & also provides 100 percent redundancy. Minimum number of drives required is 4. It is quite expensive, as you can clearly see that you are dedicating one disk per raid 1 array for redundancy. But is an excellent choice for both performance and redundancy.
Summary of different RAID levels
RAID 0 uses striping for high performance. Raid 0 cannot be considered as RAID as it does not provide fault tolerance.
RAID 1 uses mirroring for redundancy.
RAID 5 uses striping as well as parity for redundancy. It is well suited for heavy read and low write operations.
RAID 6 uses striping and double parity for redundancy.
RAID 10 is a combination of raid 1 and raid 0. It also provides heavy redundancy because of mirroring, and also provides performance as the data is striped across multiple raid 1 group

https://www.slashroot.in/raid-levels-raid0-raid1-raid10-raid5-raid6-complete-tutorial

questions.question_text: A network administrator is trying to provide the most resilient hard drive configuration in a server. With five hard drives, which of the following is the MOST fault- tolerant configuration?

discussion.content: EAP-TLS (Transport Layer Security) provides for certificate-based and mutual authentication of the client and the network. It relies on client-side and server-side certificate

• EAP-TLS. This is one of the most secure EAP standards and is widely implemented. The primary difference between
 PEAP and EAP-TLS is that it requires certificates on the 802.1x server and on each of the wireless clients.
Mutual authentication = EAP-TLS. Just remember that!!
mutually authenticate
Just in case it hasn't been hammered into us enough...EAP-TLS requires client side and server side cert

comments.content:
they both are for wireless networks, both are for authentication with certificates (x.509). 
TTLS requires digital certificate on the server but not on the client. The client uses password for authentication. EAP TTLS uses a server-side digital certificate and a client side password for authentication.

discussion.content: EAP_TTLS as well, wonder what is truly right. Stupid question, says nothing if server needs a cert. :/
